p: Essential oils can contain 100 individual compounds, of which only one or a few compounds often predominate, determining the chemotype [ 25]. Although the main components could be responsible for antimicrobial and other biological effects, the synergistic and additive effects functions of the various molecules of the EOs and their monoterpenoid components have been proven [ 25, 66], in addition to their antagonistic effects in a few cases [ 69]. Interestingly, the lack of resistance in bacteria to the components of EOs can also be explained by EOs containing many molecules with different antibiotic modes of action [ 70]. In fact, reports have shown the potential of EOs to decrease bacterial resistance to antibiotics [ 71].
